caption: Wow! Have been meaning to visit here for so long and was really worth the visit. Slight queue to get in but moved quickly. Wide and interesting selection of books. The upstairs reading room is a good place to have a little sit and read a purchase and take in the decor. It was quite busy when we went so be careful of backpacks! The cafe was also a good place for a welcome refreshment.

Shakespeare and Company is an iconic English-language bookstore in the heart of Paris, renowned for its literary history and charming atmosphere. With its cozy, labyrinthine interior, filled with books stacked from floor to ceiling, it offers a unique experience for book lovers. The store has a rich history, having been a gathering place for famous writers like Ernest Hemingway and James Joyce. Whether you're browsing for a new read or simply soaking in the literary ambiance, Shakespeare and Company is a must-visit for anyone with a passion for books and Parisian culture.

I'm glad I got the time and chance to visit the book store. The store is so unique it's a gem for sure. There are so many books to choose from and so many genres. Many little unique fun rooms and a sticky note pad room leave a note for one to read, hehe üìö  There was a little wait few mins don't be shy of the line the store is too cute.  Also, no picture allowed. I was given the chance for the review, and I told them . They will stop you if you take pictures.  " I'll be your light when it's dark"

Loved browsing this book store - even bought a book. Loved that they stamp it for you and give you a bookmark. No photos are allowed inside. But they have great books on sale. A big queue outside.  You have to leave your umbrella outside too, if it‚Äôs been raining.

Well regarded and I guess famous bookshop in Paris that is designed like a quaint old bookstore. It has a wide and very varied selection of English books and is under strict supervision and security - photos are strictly not allowed in the bookstore. So you'll have to experience the shop yourself. There's a reading floor and a second hand section that helps with recycling which is nice. Nice merch as well.
It‚Äôs cute but it‚Äôs quite different to what it was with almost no second hand books. The upstairs is still quite lovely and really isn‚Äôt very busy at all so have a look up there.

Really enjoyed this bookstore even with the standing in the line. The atmosphere is very cozy and chill, so many beautiful old school reader and writers spots inside, and charming that no photos are allowed. Found myself a French phrase book and non fiction about the importance of bookstores.

A truly beautiful and enriching experience that immerses you in culture and art. The ambiance was serene, and the staff was welcoming and knowledgeable. However, the experience could be even better with the inclusion of books in multiple languages to cater to a wider audience. This would allow visitors from diverse backgrounds to fully appreciate the content and history presented. Adding more language options would not only enhance accessibility but also make the experience more inclusive and memorable for everyone. A small improvement like this could elevate the overall quality of the visit.
Could spend all day in here, great selection of books. Bit pricey but worth a trip if you're a book lover.
What a great experience! A total pleasure to see the great collection of all genres of books and the world full of book lovers. Totally enjoyed my visit‚ú®

I love this bookstore so much! It's so cozy and chill; I love going there just for the experience. This place inspires me to read and write‚Äîit's like every writer and reader's dream come true.  Unfortunately for this review (but very fortunately for the integrity and ambiance of the bookstore itself, in my opinion‚Äîit's a way of preserving its charm), taking pictures inside is not allowed. I personally really appreciate the variety of languages spoken due to the presence of many tourists; it‚Äôs music to my ears (granted, I‚Äôm very passionate about languages). Don‚Äôt get me wrong, though‚Äîit‚Äôs not noisy inside at all; on the contrary, it‚Äôs a very calm place.  The staff are very friendly, though a few might not be as personable. The only minor hiccup is that, since it‚Äôs an English bookshop in Paris, if you speak both French and English, you might feel a bit unsure about which language to use when interacting with them. This can make me personally anxious‚ÄîI tend to avoid interactions altogether, haha. But this isn‚Äôt a downside at all, just a quirky observation.  If you‚Äôre visiting Paris and love books, Shakespeare and Company is an absolute must, in my opinion!

One of my all time favourite places in Paris. An old bookstore, established in 1951 where loads of famous authors also came to visit.  Shakespeare and company has two stores, one for new books and one for old preloved ones and there is also a cafe on the left that offers everything from breakfast to afternoon cakes, also a lot of vegan options and vegan milk for the coffee specialities.  All of the books that you can purchase here are written in English and the staff speaks english as well. I got a copy from hamlet there that was bilingual (english and French) and the last time I visited I bought a book from the antiquarian part of SaC. I was very seduced to also buy a copy of the complete works of Shakespeare which arrived just that day but I feared that my bag would get too heavy so I didn't do it haha.  Last bit not least I can say that it's definitely worth a visit if you're in Paris, the stores as well as the cafe!

We had to stop here just based on the reviews. A line to get in. They definitely don't want you taking pictures inside..... Great variety of books and genres Didn't buy any.... Suitcases already full to the brim!

A beautiful must see for book lovers who visit Paris. Free to visit, and only a short queue to enter which moves quickly, however once inside you are able to spend as long as you want and the place is quiet, incredibly well set out and it is as if you‚Äôve entered another world. Upstairs is a floor for reading. With every purchase they offer you a free stamp and bookmark (per book) no matter how much you spend/how many books, which is a thoughtful touch. Attached to the main bookstore is a second hand store as well as a cafe. You can honestly find books of all types, genres and for all ages. Cannot recommend this gem enough - a definite highlight of my trip.

Believe the hype! Resting in the shadow of Notre Dame, this relatively small bookstore is a treasure in and of itself. This place is amazing with wall-to-wall English books and a small used section next door. This bookstore covers every genre you might want to investigate or that you already enjoy. The best part of all is that whatever book you purchase, they stamp the inside with their unique logo (a small but thoughtful memento).  Truly this is a great bookstore, a must see in Paris.

The iconic Shakespeare and Company - nestled right next to Seine and the mighty Notre Dame is zero km for Paris and an absolute pilgrimage for readers, artists, writers and tourists.  It has limited capacity which means there is often a queue outside but absolutely worth the wait. The place has well a lot of books of all genres and great assortment in terms of cataloguing and staff recommendations.  The first floor has a reading room which has old world charm and quite an inspiring aura.  Next to the shop is also a bakery and antique/ second hand books and newsletter store. Highly recommend to visit.  Can always bank on the place to meet like minded fellow curious readers from across the globe. And you can count on the staff to share your excitement on Paris, the book you are buying and share reviews and recommendations.
Somewhat friendly staff. Had a long, intimidating line in front to enter the store.  Lovely restaurant to it's side  with a yummy Baba au Rhum for dessert.  Pleasant surroundings.

Went on a Wed at 430pm and the line was fairly short, took about 10 mins to enter. It wasn't too crowded during my time as well.  They have a large selection in English as a FYI. Upstairs, there is a reading area where you can just hangout and enjoy the space. It's designed well and interesting to think of all the great minds who occupied this shop.  The only downside is the inflated prices but I guess that's to be expected in this type of place. They will also offer to stamp any book purchase which is a nice lil touch

Not that ‚ÄúIconic‚Äù  The original ‚ÄúShakespeare and Company‚Äù was founded by Sylvia Beach in 1919 at different address and was the one where Hemingway and Fitzgerald would gathered. This one was opened much later by different name, which has been changed later. Despite huge queue place is still nice to visit, tho some books are a little overpriced.

Disregard those that mock you for doing the tourist thing by visiting this iconic bookshop with a reputation for having helped launch the writing careers of such greats as James Joyce.  First opened by Sylvia Beach in 1919, the Parisian institution was frequented by writers including Fitzgerald, Hemingway, Eliot and Joyce in the early 20th century. The shop was nicknamed "Stratford-on-Od√©on" by Joyce, who used it as his office. Beach published Joyce's book Ulysses in 1922. Apparently these literary greats would write and hang out here and sometimes even use it as a crash pad.  Go here and browse the books for sale then head upstairs and read or write in a cozy corner. If you wish, feel free to purchase a book bag or two to bring home for yourself and a friend. Free events are also held such as last night‚Äôs 7pm author talk. Caf√© next door to while away some more time and look across the Seine at renovations of Notre Dame.

Shakespeare and Company offers a charming experience with a quick-moving line and friendly service. Inside, you'll find a wide selection of books and literary treasures. A must-visit for book lovers in Paris.

Such a beautiful and cozy book shop, I love that they offer to stamp your books and give you free bookmarks with your purchase. The perfect souvenir for your trip to Paris. I purchased 2 books for myself and my sister in law as she is a book lover. She was beyond excited with the gift. I would definitely return again :)  Note that they don‚Äôt allow photos inside even though there are many on here.

One employee in particular was extremely rude. The place is very popular and touristy. Hence, the reason why so many tourists like to take pictures of themselves as a souvenir. The shop policy is not to take photos so to respect others‚Äô privacy. I was informed by this when I was holding my tripod and I apologized for that. However having being in a corner of the shop with no customers or employees around, I snapped a photo as a souvenir to keep for my own self. Visiting this place was on my bucket list. The last thing I wanted is to invade people‚Äôs privacy, but I wanted to keep a special memory for myself. While paying my bill at the counter, the employee asked me in an angry tone to delete the video in front of other customers because apparently he was watching me through the camera the whole time. He wouldn‚Äôt budge from my side until I have paid my bill. I explained that it was only a photo of my face. He proceeded to demand me to delete it because he was claiming he was in the background! He was staring at my phone and at one point I thought he‚Äôd snatch my phone from me and attempt to delete it himself. He escorted me to the door like I was some theirs. He said he doesn‚Äôt want his face on social media. I explained that I‚Äôm not planning to post his face in my socials, why would I even wanna do that. I understand his viewpoint, but being talked to in that angry tone as if I am a criminal of some sort was not in my expectations while planning to visit this place. I informed him later that I was spoken to in a disrespectful way. He continued to show attitude and tell me that‚Äôs because I have no respect. He didn‚Äôt apologize once for the way he addressed me. Such a popular place with low quality employee indeed.
If you visit here, please ask someone to tell you the story of this place. It's beautiful ‚ù§Ô∏è Exactly what you'd expect of an old bookstore. No photos allowed so I only have the outer entrance.

The bookstore has a really nice atmosphere created by warm lighting and "old timey" interior design, but also nice organization of books by topic (couldn't add photos because the place doesn't allow photos inside). All the books I saw were in English with rare exceptions. Second floor of library is reserved for reading. We had to wait in line for about 10-15 min but inside it wasn't crowded or anything like that. The staff seemed a little overwhelmed and "in a hurry" hurrying through the rooms and carrying around books!

Truly a must see if you are in Paris! I saw someone walking with a tote bag in Paris and I decided to google what this is. Online, I saw a great bookstore I had to visit! I got there early Saturday morning at 10am. It wasn't crowded yet and the bookstore is super fun to visit. There are 'rooms' with books everywhere, lots of books. They also have seating areas where you can read books, a piano and a caf√©. Of course, I bought a tote bag!

I love quaint bookshops around Europe but just can't love this one.  This is now more of a crowded tourist sight and managed like so, with a security guard managing the long line of people to enter, and the shop is packed that you can't comfortably browse at all.  The second floor reading room is decorated by "books by the foot".  The second hand books in front of the shop are much more expensive (4 euro) than other local bookshops too (1 euro).

I can‚Äôt believe I‚Äôm giving 4 stars because I ADORE this place and had always wanted to come here. It‚Äôs lovely and whimsical and everything you want a bookshop to be. However, it‚Äôs located right next to the Seine and carries almost zero French books. Nearly everything is in English. Just felt strange for a Parisian bookstore. They do stamp your book for you (if you wish) and it‚Äôs a great keepsake.
LOVE this place. Grat books, great people. The security guard was so nice and funny. They even have a reading area upstairs AND are dog friendly! 10 out of 10
No need to write about the endless selection of books because it's pretty well known, but the coffee was perhaps the best coffee I've ever had in Paris!
A legendary and very charming bookshop. You feel like you are in a movie. I loved the fact that you can‚Äôt take pictures inside. That way you can really experience the moment.
Lovely cafe - great coffee and ambience nestled by the Notre Dame cathedral and the latin quarter. A lovely spot for a break.

It is a cute and cozy bookstore. I visited on a weekend around 5:00 PM. I wouldn‚Äôt say the line is huge but yes there is waiting time to get into the store. Like ten minutes. The store itself has huge collection of books of different genres. If you buy a book , you can get it stamped. You cannot take photos or videos inside the store.
It‚Äôs a good place to explore, an interesting place to visit. Lots of English books.

There is alone to get in. Line moves fast. ƒ∞t is like a very old book store that has became touristic place by the time. ƒ∞t is worth to see it. They don't allow taking pictures inside. You can buy books and used books. Next to it there is a coffee shop that is called Shakespeare and Company coffee shop. Didn't try coffee at that shop. ƒ∞nside is a bit crowded. There are books for all tastes. You can't visit as large groups, they have rule says that large groups are not allowed.

The first time I tried to go was Sunday, an hour before close. The line was too long so I knew I wouldn‚Äôt be able to make it in, because they only allow a few people at a time to shop. Instead I browsed the used bookstore which definitely leans more vintage/antique/collector editions. Then there is the cafe which has coffe/tea/snacks and some merch items including the tote bags.  When I went Monday evening I was able to walk right in (it was also a bit gloomy out). It‚Äôs a nice book store, and I didn‚Äôt go upstairs but there‚Äôs a reading room with books you can look at/read but not purchase. Staff was friendly, I got a book and a postcard. My only critique is they claim to have ‚Äúused books,‚Äù but the selection is limited to one small book case in the back with about 30 titles nobody has ever heard of. Not what I was expecting.

It is much larger than it looks like. It‚Äôs a rich collection of books. I spent like 30minutes to discover, it was fun. They have nice souvenirs like pins, tshirts etc. There might be a long line but in my experience wait time wasn‚Äôt that long.

A library with a lot of history and a vibe that makes you want to stay and read in one of its cozy corners. There are armchairs and spaces that invite you to linger and read for a while, especially on the upper floor.
